February 17 – The British recognize the independence of the Orange Free State in Southern Africa; its official independence is declared six days later in the Orange River Convention.
May 27 – Taiping Rebellion: United States diplomatic minister Robert McLane arrives at the Heavenly Capital aboard the USS Susquehanna.
October 6 – The great fire of Newcastle and Gateshead in England is ignited by a spectacular explosion.
Henry Bessemer files his patent in the United Kingdom for the Bessemer process of steelmaking.
February 15 – The North Carolina General Assembly incorporates the Western North Carolina Railroad, to build a rail line from Salisbury to the western part of the state.
January 27 – The Panama Railway becomes the first railroad to connect the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

April 7 – Battle of Kaba: The Kingdom of Tonga in the islands of the southwest Pacific Ocean (Polynesia, Melanesia / Oceania), intervenes in the war between the self-proclaimed Tui Viti of the island of Fiji, Cakobau, and his rivals the Confederation of Rewa. It results in Rewa's defeat and the tenuous unification of Fiji under Cakobau.
July 16 – The Australian Colonies are granted self-governing status by the United Kingdom.
August 10 – The Last Island hurricane destroys Last Island, Louisiana, leaving 400 dead. The whole island is broken up into several smaller islands by the storm.
July 14–15 – In Spain, General Leopoldo O'Donnell takes control of the government, bringing an end to the bienio progresista.
May 21 – Sacking of Lawrence: Lawrence, Kansas, is captured and burned by pro-slavery forces.
February 7 – The Nawab of Oudh, Wajid Ali Shah, is exiled to Metiabruz and the state is annexed by the British East India Company.
The 223-mile North Carolina Railroad is completed from Goldsboro through Raleigh and Salisbury to Charlotte.
La Tène culture artifacts are discovered in Switzerland, by Hansli Kopp.
December 31 – Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa as the capital of Canada.
September 20 – Indian Rebellion of : British forces recapture Delhi, compelling the surrender of Bahadur Shah II, the last Mughal emperor.
May 11 – Indian Rebellion of : Indian combatants capture Delhi from the British East India Company.
April 8 – Mangal Pandey is hanged for mutiny against the British East India Company army; the execution is a precursor event to the Indian Rebellion of.
April 19 – The United States signs a treaty with the Yankton Sioux Tribe.
June 16 – Abraham Lincoln accepts the Republican Party nomination for a seat in the United States Senate, delivering his House Divided speech in Springfield, Illinois.
August 7 – A football match, played under an unknown set of rules, is held between Melbourne Grammar School and Scotch College.

The Government of India Act, passed by the Parliament of the United Kingdom, transfers the territories of the British East India Company and their administration to the direct rule of the British Crown, through a Secretary of State for India.
Pike's Peak Gold Rush: Fifty-Niners stream into the Rocky Mountains of the western United States.

February 4 – German scholar Constantin von Tischendorf rediscovers the Codex Sinaiticus, a 4th-century uncial manuscript of the Greek Bible, in Saint Catherine's Monastery on the foot of Mount Sinai, in the Khedivate of Egypt and arranges for its presentation to his patron, Tsar Alexander II of Russia at Saint Petersburg.
April 13 – The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art is founded by Peter Cooper, a New York industrialist, inventor and philanthropist.
Nillmij, a predecessor of Aegon, Dutch-based worldwide insurance company, is founded in the Dutch East Indies (modern Indonesia).
The University of Michigan Law School is founded.
February 2 – Miguel Miramón (–) becomes Conservative interim President of Mexico.
October 6 – Section 377 of the British Indian penal code was enacted in British India.
December 24 – Mexico's interim president Miguel Miramón flees the country after being defeated in battle.
Meeting at Teano: Giuseppe Garibaldi gives Naples to King Victor Emmanuel II, recognizing him as King of Italy.
October 19 – A new Māori revolt begins in New Zealand.
Christians and Druzes clash in Damascus, Syria.

March 20
Unification of Italy: The surrender of Civitella del Tronto ends the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
An earthquake completely destroys Mendoza, Argentina.
October 28 – The Missouri legislature takes up a bill for Missouri's secession from the Union.
August 10 – American Civil War: The first major battle west of the Mississippi River, the Battle of Wilson's Creek, is fought, with a Confederate victory.

American Civil War:
November 6 – Jefferson Davis is elected president of the Confederate States of America.
November 7 – Battle of Belmont – In Belmont, Missouri, Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant (in his first combat leadership role) overrun a Confederate camp, but are forced to retreat when Confederate reinforcements arrive.
November 8 – Trent Affair – The USS San Jacinto stops the United Kingdom mail ship Trent, and arrests two Confederate envoys, James Mason and John Slidell, sparking a diplomatic crisis between the U.K. and U.S.
November 28 – Acting on the ordinance passed by the Jackson government, the Confederate Congress admits Missouri as the 12th Confederate state.

September 17 – American Civil War:
Battle of Antietam: Union forces strategically defeat Confederate troops at Sharpsburg, Maryland, in the bloodiest day in U.S. history, with over 22,000 casualties.
The Allegheny Arsenal explosion results in the single largest civilian disaster during the war, with 78 workers – mostly young women – being killed.
May 5 – Second French intervention in Mexico: Battle of Puebla – Mexican General Ignacio Zaragoza defeats the French Army; commemorated each year as Cinco de Mayo (Spanish for Fifth of May).

September 22
Otto von Bismarck becomes Minister President of Prussia, following refusal by the country's Landtag to accept the military budget.
American Civil War: The preliminary announcement of the Emancipation Proclamation is made by U.S. President Abraham Lincoln: From January 1,, slaves in the Confederate States will be considered free.

Dakota War of : During an uprising in Minnesota, Dakota warriors decide not to attack heavily defended Fort Ridgely and instead turn to the settlement of New Ulm, killing white settlers along the way.

September 5 – In the Confederacy's first invasion of the North, General Robert E. Lee leads 55,000 men of the Army of Northern Virginia across the Potomac River at White's Ford near Leesburg, Virginia, into Maryland.
October 15 – The Confederate submarine H. L. Hunley sinks during a test, killing Horace Lawson Hunley (its inventor) and a crew of seven.
Bartolomé Mitre secretly backs the revolt of Venancio Flores against the Uruguayan Blanco government.

November 26 – Mine Run – Union forces under General George Meade position against troops led by Confederate General Robert E. Lee (Meade's forces cannot find any weaknesses in the Confederate lines, and give up trying after five days).
May 31 – The first Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe horse race is held.
November 23 – Battle of Chattanooga III – Union forces led by General Ulysses S. Grant reinforce troops at Chattanooga, Tennessee, and counter-attack Confederate troops.
October 1 – A calamity is narrowly averted in London at the Erith explosion.
February 1 – Danish-Prussian War (Second Schleswig War): 57,000 Austrian and Prussian troops cross the Eider River into Denmark.
American Civil War: The Army of the Potomac, under General Ulysses S. Grant, breaks off from the Battle of the Wilderness and moves southwards.

November 4 – American Civil War: Battle of Johnsonville – At Johnsonville, Tennessee, troops under the command of Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest bombard a Union supply base with artillery, and destroy millions of dollars' worth of material.
James Clerk Maxwell presents his paper, A Dynamical Theory of the Electromagnetic Field, to the Royal Society in London, treating light as an electromagnetic wave.
July 4 – Lewis Carroll publishes his children's novel Alice's Adventures in Wonderland in England (first trade editions in December).
November 6 – American Civil War: The CSS Shenandoah, last remnant of the Confederate States of America and its military, surrenders in Liverpool after fleeing westward from the Pacific.
August 25 – The Shergotty meteorite Mars meteorite falls in Sherghati, Gaya, Bihar in India.
The Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (conditional prohibition of slavery and involuntary servitude) passes narrowly, in the House of Representatives.

January 31
The Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution (conditional prohibition of slavery and involuntary servitude) passes narrowly, in the House of Representatives.
American Civil War: Confederate General Robert E. Lee becomes general-in-chief.

March 13 – The United States Congress overwhelmingly passes the Civil Rights Act of, the first federal legislation to protect the rights of African-Americans; U.S. President Andrew Johnson vetoes the bill on March 27, and Congress overrides the veto on April 9.
December 12– Oaks explosion: The worst mining disaster in England kills 383 miners and rescuers.

January 12
The Royal Aeronautical Society is formed as The Aeronautical Society of Great Britain in London, the world's oldest such society.
British auxiliary steamer SS London sinks in a storm in the Bay of Biscay, on passage from the Thames to Australia, with the loss of 244 people, and only 19 survivors.
January 18 – Wesley College, Melbourne, is established.
July 5 – Princess Helena, third daughter of Queen Victoria, marries Prince Christian of Schleswig-Holstein.

March 30 – Alaska Purchase: Alaska is purchased for US$7.2 million from Alexander II of Russia, about 2 cents/acre ($4.19/km), by United States Secretary of State William H. Seward. Newspapers call this Seward's Folly.
January 30 – Emperor Kōmei of Japan dies suddenly, age 36, leaving his son Mutsuhito to succeed him.
Treaty of London: The great powers of Europe reaffirm the neutrality of Luxembourg, ending the Luxembourg Crisis. The Duchy of Limburg is formally re-incorporated into the Kingdom of the Netherlands.

October 21 – 'Manifest destiny': Medicine Lodge Treaty – Near Medicine Lodge Creek, Kansas, a landmark treaty is signed by southern Great Plains Indian leaders, requiring Native American Plains tribes to relocate to a reservation in western Oklahoma.
Gorse is naturalised in New Zealand, where it soon becomes the worst invasive weed.
September 28 – The Opelousas massacre, one of the bloodiest massacres of the Reconstruction era in the United States.
July 9 – The Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified.
March 24 – The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is formed, in New York City.
January 2 – British Expedition to Abyssinia: Robert Napier leads an expedition to free captive British officials and missionaries.
The first transnational women's organization, Association internationale des femmes, is founded.
The Ladies National Association for the Repeal of the Contagious Diseases Acts is founded in Great Britain.
May 4–10 – Naval Battle of Hakodate: The Imperial Japanese Navy defeats adherents of the Tokugawa shogunate.
June 15 – John Wesley Hyatt patents celluloid in Albany, New York.
The capital of the Isle of Man moves from Castletown to Douglas.

July 20
The Innocents Abroad, by Mark Twain, goes on sale after printing by the American Publishing Company. It becomes Twain's bestselling work during his lifetime.
Children's Hospital Boston is founded by Dr. Francis Henry Brown and other Harvard Medical School graduates, as a 20-bed facility in the South End of Boston, Massachusetts.
The Port Adelaide Football Club is founded.
April 11 – A 7.3 magnitude earthquake shakes the Chinese county of Batang causing a fire that leaves about 5,000 dead.

January 1
The first edition of The Northern Echo newspaper is published in Priestgate, Darlington, England.
Plans for the Brooklyn Bridge are completed.
October 2 – A plebiscite held in Rome supports, by 133,681 votes to 1,507, the annexation of the city by Italy.
March 10 – Deutsche Bank is founded in Berlin.

March 21
Otto von Bismarck becomes the first Chancellor of the German Empire.
John Campbell, Marquess of Lorne marries Princess Louise, a daughter of Queen Victoria, at Windsor; she is the first legitimate daughter of a British monarch to marry a subject since 1515.
December 15 – The Deseret Telegraph Company office in Pipe Spring begins service with a message keyed by Ella Stewart. It is the first telegraph sent from Arizona Territory.

October 27
British forces march into the Klipdrift Republic and annex the territory as Griqualand West Colony.
Henri, Count of Chambord, refuses to be crowned "King Henry V of France" until France abandons its tricolor, and returns to the old Bourbon flag.
Boss Tweed of Tammany Hall is arrested for bribery, ending his grip on New York City.
French government troops enter Paris to overthrow the Commune, beginning "Bloody Week" (Semaine sanglante), leading to the deaths of over 20,000 Parisians and the arrests of over 38,000 more.
February 9 – The United States Commission on Fish and Fisheries is founded.
January 20 – The Cavite mutiny was an uprising of Filipino military personnel of Fort San Felipe, the Spanish arsenal in Cavite, Philippine Islands.
November 11 – U.S. government geologist Clarence King reveals the diamond hoax in Wyoming.
December 3 – Assyriologist George Smith presents the first translation of the Epic of Gilgamesh, to a meeting of the Society of Biblical Archaeology in London.
The first Marist Brothers travel to Australia.
Universal public schools are called for.
The Married Woman's Property Rights Association is founded in Sweden.
The League of the Three Emperors is created. It links the conservative monarchs of Austria-Hungary, the German Empire and the Russian Empire in an alliance against radical movements.
December 15 – Women of Fredonia, New York, march against the retail liquor dealers in town, to inaugurate the Woman's Crusade of –74.
May 1 – The Vienna World's Fair opens in the capital of Austria-Hungary and runs for six months, closing on October 31.
September 25 – Classes begin at Drury University in Springfield, Missouri.

July 31 – Patrick Francis Healy, S.J., the first Black man to receive a PhD, is inaugurated as president of Georgetown University, the oldest Catholic University in America, and becomes the first Black person to head a predominantly White university.
November 6 – The University of Adelaide is founded in Australia.
Bolton Wanderers (as Christ Church F.C.).
May 16 – The Mill River dam collapses in Massachusetts, killing 139 people.

July 24
Mathew Evans and Henry Woodward patent the first incandescent lamp, with an electric light bulb.
Third Carlist War: Sack of Cuenca – After Carlist forces successfully defend Estella, Don Alfonso de Bourbon, brother of the Don Carlos VII, leads 14,000 Catalan Carlists south to attack Cuenca (136 km from Madrid), held by Republicans under Don Hilario Lozano. After two days the outnumbered garrison capitulates, but Don Alfonso permits a terrible slaughter. The city is sacked. Subsequently, another republican force defeats the disorderly Catalans, who flee back to the Ebro.
June 4 – Two American colleges play each other in arguably the first game of college football: Tufts University and Harvard University at Jarvis Field in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
The first indoor ice hockey game is played at the Victoria Skating Rink in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.
March 15 – Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York John McCloskey is named the first cardinal in the United States.
September 27 – American merchant sailing ship Ellen Southard is wrecked off Liverpool in England; 12 crew and life-boatmen are lost.
The Page Act of is enacted in the United States, effectively prohibiting the immigration of Chinese women.
July 8 – Reichstadt Agreement: Russia and Austria-Hungary agree on partitioning the Balkan Peninsula.
May 17 – Nicolaus Otto files his patent for the four-stroke cycle internal combustion engine.
December 29 – The Ashtabula River railroad disaster occurs in Ohio when a bridge collapses, leaving 92 dead.
United States presidential election: After long and heated disputes, Rutherford B. Hayes is eventually declared the winner over Samuel J. Tilden.
Heinz Tomato Ketchup is introduced in the United States.
July 19 – Russo-Turkish War: The first battle in the siege of Plevna is fought.
March 24 – For the only time in history, The Boat Race between the Universities of Oxford and Cambridge is declared a "dead heat" (i.e., a draw).
March – The Nineteenth Century magazine is founded in London.
November 22 – The first college lacrosse game is played between New York University and Manhattan University.
January 8 – Great Sioux War of : Battle of Wolf Mountain – Crazy Horse and his warriors fight their last battle with the United States Cavalry in Montana.
Ipswich Town Football Club, formed as amateur club Ipswich A.F.C. They will not turn professional until.
January 9 – Umberto I becomes King of Italy.
May 25 – Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera H.M.S. Pinafore debuts in London at the Opera Comique, with a first run of 571 performances.
January 5 – Russo-Turkish War: Battle of Shipka Pass IV – Russian and Bulgarian forces defeat the Ottoman Empire.

June 1
The General Postal Union is renamed the Universal Postal Union.
British clipper Loch Ard is wrecked off the Shipwreck Coast of Victoria with the loss of 52 lives and only 2 survivors.
October 8 – War of the Pacific: Battle of Angamos – The Chilean Navy defeats Peruvian naval forces.
March 3 – United States Geological Survey is founded.
May 14 – The first group of 463 Indian indentured labourers arrive in Fiji, aboard the Leonidas.
October 7 – The Dual Alliance is formed by Germany and Austria-Hungary.
May 26 – Russia and the United Kingdom sign the Treaty of Gandamak, establishing an Afghan state.
July 27 – Second Anglo-Afghan War – Battle of Maiwand: Afghan troops under Ayub Khan defeat British and Indian forces, under Brigadier General George Burrows.
The first electric streetlight is installed in Wabash, Indiana.
April – The government of Cape Colony sets a deadline for the Basuto people to surrender their weapons; non-compliance leads to the Basuto Gun War.
A blizzard marks the start of the Hard Winter in North America.
April 27 – The Royal University of Ireland is founded by charter, allowing the Catholic University of Ireland to re-form as University College Dublin.
November 19 – A meteorite strikes the Earth near the village of Großliebenthal, a few kilometers southwest of Odesa, Ukraine.
September 5 – The Thumb Fire in the U.S. state of Michigan destroys over a million acres (4,000 km) and kills 282 people.
July 20 – American Indian Wars: Sioux chief Sitting Bull leads the last of his people in surrender to United States troops at Fort Buford in Montana.

March 23
The First Boer War comes to an end.
A fire caused by a gas explosion destroys the Opéra de Nice in the south of France with fatalities.
New York City's oldest independent school for girls, the Convent of the Sacred Heart New York (91st Street), is founded.
Nikola Tesla claims this is when he conceives the rotating magnetic field principle, which he later uses to invent his induction motor.
November 16 – The British Royal Navy's HMS Flirt destroys Abari village in Niger.
August 5 – Standard Oil of New Jersey, the company later known as ExxonMobil, is established.
August 20 – Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky's Overture debuts in Moscow.
Ferdinand von Lindemann publishes his proof of the transcendentality of pi.
April 28 – The first rugby sevens tournament is played at Melrose RFC in Scotland.
Bernard Kroger establishes the first Kroger grocery store, in Cincinnati, Ohio.
August 26–27 – eruption of Krakatoa: The volcanic island of Krakatoa erupts at 10:02 am (local time); 163 villages are destroyed, 36,417 killed by tsunami.
July 4 – The world's first rodeo is held in Pecos, Texas.

Founding of:
Houghton College in New York State
Wagner College in New York City
Baltimore Polytechnic Institute in Maryland
Raith Rovers F.C. in Scotland
The Black Arabs F.C (later Bristol Rovers) in England
Dunstable Town F.C. in England.
Angelo Moriondo of Turin is granted a patent for an espresso machine.
January 5 – Gilbert and Sullivan's comic opera Princess Ida, a satire on feminism, premières at the Savoy Theatre, London.
November 15 – The Berlin Conference, which regulates European colonisation and trade in Africa, begins (ends February 26, ).
July 1 – First International Forestry Exhibition opens in Edinburgh, Scotland.
April 4 – The Treaty of Valparaiso, an armistice between Chile and Bolivia, ends the War of the Pacific; Bolivia is obliged to cede Antofagasta to Chile, leaving Bolivia as a landlocked country.
January 20 – American inventor LaMarcus Adna Thompson patents a roller coaster.
February 20 – The Richmond Football Club is officially formed at the Royal Hotel in the Melbourne suburb of Richmond, Victoria.

May 2
Good Housekeeping magazine goes on sale for the first time in the United States.
North-West Rebellion: Battle of Cut Knife – Cree and Assiniboine warriors win their largest victory over Canadian forces.
North-West Rebellion: Battle of Cut Knife – Cree and Assiniboine warriors win their largest victory over Canadian forces.
July 14 – Sarah E. Goode is the first African-American woman to apply for and receive a patent, for the invention of the hideaway bed.
August 19 – The Christian Union (Church of God) is established in Monroe County, Tennessee.
May 15 – Portugal and France agree to regulate the borders of their colonies in Guinea.
Johnson & Johnson, which becomes a multinational brand, begins manufacturing healthcare products in New Jersey, United States.

December 11 – London Association football club Arsenal, founded as Dial Square by workers at the Royal Arsenal in Woolwich, play their first match (on the Isle of Dogs). The club is renamed Royal Arsenal soon afterwards, supposedly on December 25.
April 4 – William Ewart Gladstone introduces the First Irish Home Rule Bill in the Parliament of the United Kingdom; it is defeated on June 8.
British emigrant ship Kapunda sinks after a collision off the coast of Brazil, killing 303 with only 16 survivors.

January 28
In a snowstorm at Fort Keogh, Montana, the largest snowflakes on record are reported. They are 15 inches (38 cm) wide and 8 inches (20 cm) thick.
Construction work begins on the foundations of the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France.
October 18 – Johannes Brahms conducts the premiere of his Double Concerto, composed for violinist Joseph Joachim and cellist Robert Hausmann.
February 4 – The Interstate Commerce Act of, passed by the 49th United States Congress, is signed into law by President Grover Cleveland.
January 11 – Louis Pasteur's anti-rabies treatment is defended in the Académie Nationale de Médecine, by Dr. Joseph Grancher.
September 17 – Las Cruces College (later New Mexico State University) is founded in Las Cruces, New Mexico.
February 27 – In West Orange, New Jersey, Thomas Edison meets with Eadweard Muybridge, who proposes a scheme for sound film.
October 25 – St Cuthbert's Society at the University of Durham in England is founded, after a general meeting chaired by the Reverend Hastings Rashdall.
August 31 – Whitechapel murders: The mutilated body of London prostitute Mary Ann Nichols is found; she is considered the first victim of Jack the Ripper.

July 25 – Frank Edward McGurrin, a court stenographer from Salt Lake City, Utah, purportedly the only person using touch typing at this time, wins a decisive victory over Louis Traub in a typing contest held in Cincinnati, Ohio. This date can be called the birthday of the touch typing method that is widely used in modern times.
September 10 – Albert Honoré Charles Grimaldi becomes Albert I, Prince of Monaco.
January 15 – The Coca-Cola Company is originally incorporated as the Pemberton Medicine Company in Atlanta, Georgia.
April – British chemists Frederick Abel and James Dewar file their first patent for the smokeless propellant cordite.

March 31 – The Eiffel Tower is inaugurated in Paris (opens May 6). At 300 m (980 ft), its height exceeds the previous tallest structure in the world by 130 m (430 ft). Contemporary critics regard it as aesthetically displeasing.
August 6 – The Savoy Hotel in London opens.
August 6 – At Auburn Prison in New York, William Kemmler becomes the first person to be executed in the electric chair.
September 19 – The University of North Texas is founded, as the Texas Normal College and Teacher Training Institute.
The Ouija board is first released by Elijah Bond.
Brown trout are introduced into the upper Firehole River, in Yellowstone National Park.
February 5 – The worldwide insurance and financial service brand Allianz is founded in Berlin, Germany.

October 1
Stanford University in California opens its doors. October 1 Stanford University opens its doors.
Skansen is established as the world's first open-air museum by Artur Hazelius, on the island of Djurgården in Stockholm, Sweden.
May 11 – Ōtsu incident: Tsesarevich Nikolay Alexandrovich (the future Czar Nicholas II) of Russia survives an assassination attempt while visiting Japan.
St. Mary's Cathedral is dedicated in San Francisco.
January 29 – Liliuokalani is proclaimed Queen of Hawaii.

March 9–12 – The Great Blizzard of in the south and west of England leads to extensive snow drifts and powerful storms off the south coast, with 14 ships sunk, and approximately 220 deaths attributed to the weather conditions.
October 31 – The first collection of Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes stories from The Strand Magazine, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes, is published in London.
January 1 – Ellis Island begins processing immigrants to the United States.

March 15
The Liverpool Football Club is founded in England by John Houlding, the owner of Anfield; Houlding decides to form his own team after Everton leaves Anfield, in an argument over rent.
Jesse W. Reno patents the first escalator, installed at Coney Island.

October 5
The Dalton Gang, attempting to rob two banks in Coffeyville, Kansas, is shot by the townspeople; only Emmett Dalton, with 23 wounds, survives, to spend 14 years in prison.
Master criminal Adam Worth is captured in Liège, Belgium, during an attempted robbery of a money delivery cart.
June 5 – An oil fire in Oil City, Pennsylvania, United States, kills 130 people.
New Zealand becomes the first country in the world to grant women's suffrage.
Swami Vivekananda delivers an inspiring paper at the World Parliament of Religions in Chicago.
September 1 – William Ewart Gladstone's Government of Ireland Bill, intended to give Ireland self-government, is rejected by the U.K. Parliament.
September 23 – The Baháʼí Faith is first publicly mentioned in the United States, at the World Parliament of Religions in Chicago.

November 12 – The Durand Line is established as the boundary between British India and Afghanistan, by a memorandum of understanding signed by Sir Mortimer Durand, Foreign Secretary of British India, and Abdur Rahman Khan, Amir of Afghanistan.
December 6 – Kate Chopin's feminist short story "The Story of an Hour" is first published, in the American magazine Vogue.
May – Third plague pandemic: Bubonic plague breaks out in the Tai Ping Shan area of Hong Kong (by the end of the year, the death toll is 2,552 people); it also breaks out this year in Canton.
November 6 – Republicans win by a landslide in the United States House of Representatives elections, which sets the stage for the decisive presidential election of.

May 1 – In the United States:
Coxey's Army arrives in Washington; Coxey is arrested on the Capitol grounds.
The May Day Riots (against unemployment) break out in Cleveland, Ohio.
March 2 – William Gladstone resigns as British Prime Minister.
January 24 – An effort to restore the Hawaiian monarchy ends as the former Queen Liliʻuokalani abdicates and pledges allegiance to the Republic of Hawaii.

April 17 – The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed between China and Japan. This marks the end of the First Sino-Japanese War, and the defeated Qing Empire is forced to renounce its claims on Korea, and to concede the southern portion of Fengtian province, Taiwan and the Penghu to Japan. The huge indemnity exacted from China is used to establish the Yawata Iron and Steel Works in Japan.
The Fourth Anglo-Ashanti War begins.
June 21 – The Kiel Canal, connecting the North Sea to the Baltic across the base of the Jutland peninsula in Germany, is officially opened.
November 25 – Oscar Hammerstein opens the Olympia Theatre, the first theatre to be built in New York City's Times Square district.
August – The Eastern North America heat wave kills 1,500 people from Chicago, Illinois to Boston, Massachusetts.
July 26 – The International Socialist Workers and Trade Union Congress opens in London.
France establishes an administrative post in Abengourou, Ivory Coast.
September 30 – Italy and France sign a treaty whereby Italy virtually recognizes Tunisia as a French dependency.
Pope Leo XIII is filmed, making him the first ever Pope to be filmed and the earliest-born person to be captured on film. (Note: to view the event in the video above, go to timestamp 3:07).
July 25 – Writer Jack London sails to join the Klondike Gold Rush, where he will write his first successful stories.
Alexander Scriabin publishes his Piano Sonata no. 2 "Sonata-Fantasia" in G sharp minor.
April 19 – The first Boston Marathon is held in the United States, with fifteen men competing, and is won by John McDermott.
September 11 – After months of searching, generals of Menelik II of Ethiopia capture Gaki Sherocho, the last king of Kaffa, bringing an end to that ancient kingdom.
April 18 – the Greco-Turkish War of Breaks out.
November 9 – In the U.S., the racial violence in Phoenix, South Carolina, comes to an end after 12 African-Americans had been lynched.
November 28 –The Spanish peace commissioners in Paris announce that they accept the offer of the U.S. to purchase the Philippines.

November 26 –
General Ramón Blanco resigns as the spanish Governor-General of Cuba and is replaced by General Adolfo Jiménez Castellanos.
A two-day blizzard known as the Portland Gale piles snow in Boston, severely impacting the Massachusetts fishing industry and several coastal New England towns.
The U.S. Marines arrive on USS Boston at Tientsin in China in order to guard the American legation at Beijing.
June 10 – Tuone Udaina, the last known speaker of the Dalmatian language, is killed in an explosion.
November 27 – All 115 people aboard the American steamer SS Portland are killed when the ship founders off of the coast of Cape Cod.

June 30 – 'Mile-a-Minute Murphy' earns his nickname after he becomes the first man to ride a bicycle for one-mile (1.6 km) in under a minute, on Long Island. Murphy pedals his bike one mile in 57.8 seconds for an average speed of 62.28 miles per hour.
September 29 – The Veterans of Foreign Wars is founded in the U.S. by Spanish–American War veteran James C. Putnam as the American Veterans of Foreign Service.
Guglielmo Marconi successfully transmits a radio signal across the English Channel.
The United Kingdom announces that it has completed the purchase of rights to occupy the Kingdom of Tonga.
November 15 – The American Line's SS St. Paul becomes the first ocean liner to report her imminent arrival by wireless telegraphy.
January – The first Michelin Guide is published for French motorists.
July 2 – The first zeppelin airship flight, by Zeppelin LZ 1, is carried out over Lake Constance, near Friedrichshafen, Germany.
May 28 – Boxer Rebellion: Boxers attack Belgians in the Fengtai railway station.
July 23 – 25 – The First Pan-African Conference is held in London.
November 6 – United States presidential election: Republican incumbent William McKinley is re-elected by defeating Democratic challenger William Jennings Bryan in a rematch.
: Shamshi-Adad I conquers Assur and emerges as the first Amorite king of Assyria.
: Minoan Old Palace period starts in Crete.
: Senusret III inspects the Nubian frontier, he leads four punitive campaigns against the Nubians.
: Senwosret II (Twelfth Dynasty) died.
: The Mokaya along the Pacific coast of present-day Chiapas, Mexico were preparing cacao beverages.

January 9 – Lord Kitchener reports that Christiaan de Wet has shot one of the "peace" envoys, and flogged two more, who had gone to his commando to ask the Burgher citizens of South Africa to halt fighting.
Leon Czolgosz is executed in the electric chair for the assassination of William McKinley in Buffalo, New York on September 6.
The first showing of Picasso's paintings in Paris as the 19-year-old Spanish artist exhibits his work at Ambroise Vollard's gallery.
February 27 – The Sultan of Turkey orders 50,000 troops to the Bulgarian frontier because of unrest in Macedonia.
Chi-hsui and Hsu-cheng-yu, Boxer Rebellion leaders, are executed in Peking.
Construction of the Paul Doumer Bridge, linking both sections of Hanoi, is completed.
April 2 – The Electric Theatre, the first movie theater in the United States, opens in Los Angeles.
March 7 – Second Boer War: Battle of Tweebosch – South African Boers win their last battle over the British Army, with the capture of a British general and 200 of his men.
May 20 – Cuba gains independence from the United States.
November 16 – A newspaper cartoon depicting U.S. President "Teddy" Roosevelt refusing to shoot a bear cub inspires creation of the first teddy bear by Morris Michtom in New York City.
January 19 – The first west–east transatlantic radio broadcast is made from the United States to England (the first east–west broadcast having been made in ).
November 18 – The Hay–Bunau-Varilla Treaty is signed by the United States and Panama, giving the U.S. exclusive rights over the Panama Canal Zone.
March 14 – The Hay–Herrán Treaty, granting the United States the right to build the Panama Canal, is ratified by the United States Senate. The Colombian senate later rejects the treaty.
November 17 – The Russian Social Democratic Labour Party splits into two groups: the Bolsheviks (Russian for "majority") and Mensheviks (Russian for "minority").
August 4 – Pope Pius X succeeds Pope Leo XIII as the 257th pope.
Danish ocean liner SS Norge runs aground and sinks close to Rockall, killing approximately 627 people, many of whom are Russian-Polish and Scandinavian emigrants.
February 23 – For $10 million, the United States gains control of the Panama Canal Zone.
May 30 – Alpha Gamma Delta, which becomes an international sorority, is founded by 11 women at Syracuse University.

May 4
United States Army engineers begin work on the Panama Canal.
Charles Rolls and Henry Royce meet for the first time, in Manchester England to agree production of Rolls-Royce motor cars; the first produced under their joint names are launched in December.
German Association football club FC Schalke 04 is established.

April 8
The Entente Cordiale is signed between the UK and France.
Longacre Square in Midtown Manhattan is renamed Times Square, after The New York Times.
February 3 – The first performance of A Shropshire Lad, the setting to music of the set of 63 poems of A. E. Housman by Arthur Somervell as a song-cycle, takes place at Aeolian Hall in London.

November 17
Queen Astrid of Belgium (d. )
Mischa Auer, Russian-American actor (d. ).
Mischa Auer, Russian-American actor (d. ).
January 30 – The U.S. Supreme Court renders its unanimous decision in the landmark case of Swift & Co. v. United States, allowing the federal government to regulate monopolies.
October 11 – The Institute of Musical Art, predecessor of the Juilliard School, opens in New York City.
June 7 – Cunard liner RMS Lusitania is launched in Glasgow, as the world's largest ship.
Aleutian Islands earthquake: An earthquake with an estimated magnitude of 8.35 occurs off the Rat Islands in Alaska.
December 30 – The All-India Muslim League is founded as a political party in Dhaka in the British Raj; it becomes a driving force for the creation of an independent Pakistan.

November 3 – SOS becomes adopted internationally as a distress signal (originally for ship-to-shore wireless telegraphy) on inclusion in the service regulations of the first International Radiotelegraph Convention signed in Berlin and coming into effect on 1 July.

October 11 – A United States diplomatic crisis with Japan arises when the San Francisco public school board orders Japanese students to be taught in racially segregated schools (it is resolved by next year).
December 6 – Monongah Mining disaster: A coal mine explosion kills 362 workers in Monongah, West Virginia.
June 26 – Tiflis bank robbery: Bolsheviks attack a cash-filled bank coach in the centre of Tiflis, Georgia, killing 40 people.
April 7 – Hershey Park opens in Hershey, Pennsylvania.
The steamship Congo collides at the mouth of the Ems River with the German steamship Nerissa; 7 lives are lost.
The Autochrome Lumière is the first commercial color photography process.
April 20 – Sunshine rail disaster: A rear-end collision of two trains in Melbourne, Australia kills 44 people and injures more than 400.
July 6 – Robert Peary sets sail for the North Pole.
November 3 – United States presidential election: Republican candidate William Howard Taft defeats William Jennings Bryan, 321 electoral votes to 162.
Arthur Mee's The Children's Encyclopædia begins publication in London.
July 19 – Feyenoord, the first Dutch football club to win the UEFA Champions League, is founded at Rotterdam, Netherlands.
April 6 – Robert Peary, Matthew Henson and four Inuit explorers – Ootah, Ooqueah, Seegloo and Egigingwah – come within a few miles of the North Pole.

January 9 – The British Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole, led by Ernest Shackleton, arrives at the farthest south reached by any prior expedition, at 88°23' S, prior to turning back due to diminishing supplies.
April 19 – The Anglo-Persian Oil Company (modern-day BP) is incorporated.
December 23 – King Albert I of Belgium succeeds his uncle, Leopold II (died December 17), on the throne.
March 10 – The Anglo-Siamese Treaty of is signed in Bangkok.
Approximate date of origin of Manchurian plague, a form of pneumonic plague which by December is spreading through northeastern China, killing more than 40,000.

February 13 – The strike, begun on November 23,, by 20,000 women against New York City's shirtwaist factories ends after 339 manufacturers agree to a reduced workweek (52 hours a week rather than 56), increased wages and labor union recognition.
August 28 – Montenegro is proclaimed an independent kingdom, under Nicholas I.

November 20 – The Mexican Revolution begins, when Francisco I. Madero proclaims the elections of null and void, and calls for an armed revolution at 6 p.m. against the illegitimate presidency/dictatorship of Porfirio Díaz.
June 22 – DELAG Zeppelin dirigible Deutschland makes the first commercial passenger flight, from Friedrichshafen to Düsseldorf in Germany; the flight takes 9 hours.
October 10 – The Wuchang Uprising starts the Xinhai Revolution that leads to the founding of the Republic of China.
The first official air mail flight, second overall, takes place in British India from Allahabad to Naini when Henri Pequet carries 6,500 letters a distance of 13 km.

January 3 Kebin earthquake: An earthquake of 7.7 moment magnitude strikes near Almaty in Russian Turkestan, killing 450 or more people.
Siege of Sidney Street in London: Two Latvian anarchists die, after a seven-hour siege against a combined police and military force. Home Secretary Winston Churchill arrives to oversee events.
July 28 – The Australasian Antarctic Expedition begins as the SY Aurora departs London.
RMS Olympic departs New York for her maiden eastbound voyage home to Southampton, England.
October 10 – The Maternity Allowance Act goes into effect in Australia, but excludes minorities.
November 25 – Românul de la Pind, the longest-running newspaper by and about Aromanians until World War II, ceases publication.
October 14 – John Flammang Schrank attempts to assassinate Theodore Roosevelt in Milwaukee.
April 18 – Cunard Line vessel RMS Carpathia arrives in New York with the 705 RMS Titanic survivors.
January 1 – The Republic of China is established.
December 23 – The Federal Reserve System is created as the central banking system of the United States, by Woodrow Wilson's signature of the Federal Reserve Act.
August 2 – The first known ascent of Mount Olympus in Greece is made by Swiss mountaineers Daniel Baud-Bovy and Frédéric Boissonnas guided by Christos Kakkalos.

September 9
In Germany, BASF starts the world's first plant for the production of fertilizer based on the Haber-Bosch process, feeding in modern times about a third of the world's population.
Imperial Russian Army pilot Pyotr Nesterov becomes the first person to loop an airplane, flying a Nieuport IV monoplane over Syretzk Aerodrome near Kiev, in the Russian Empire.
Helgoland Island air disaster: The first fatalities aboard a German airship occur, when the Imperial German Navy Zeppelin dirigible LZ 14 (naval designation L 1) is forced down into the North Sea off Heligoland during a thunderstorm, killing 16 of the 22 men on board.
The city of Canberra, the center of the Australian Capital Territory, becomes the official capital of the Commonwealth of Australia.
May 26 (May 13 O.S.) – Igor Sikorsky becomes the first person to pilot a 4-engine fixed-wing aircraft.
August 26–27 – Battle of Le Cateau: British, French, and Belgian forces make a successful tactical retreat from the German advance.
The Burdur earthquake occurs in Turkey.
The British Fleet is reviewed at Spithead, by George V.
April 22 – Mexico ends diplomatic relations with the United States for the time being.
February 13 – Copyright: In New York City, the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers is established, to protect the copyrighted musical compositions of its members.

May 27 – Armenian genocide: The Tehcir Law is promulgated by the Turkish Ottoman Empire authorizing deportation of the Ottoman Armenian population to Deir ez-Zor in the Syrian desert, leading to the deaths of anywhere between 800,000 and over 1,500,000 civilians and confiscation of their property.
June 16 – Women's Institutes are established in Britain.
December 10 – The 1 millionth Ford car rolls off the assembly line at the River Rouge Plant in Detroit, Michigan.

December 4–18 – The 'Peace Ship' Oscar II chartered by industrialist Henry Ford sails from Hoboken, New Jersey to Oslo on an independent and eventually unsuccessful mission to broker a peace conference.

March 14 – WWI:
Battle of Más a Tierra: Off the coast of Chile, the British Royal Navy forces the Imperial German Navy light cruiser SMS Dresden (last survivor of the German East Asia Squadron) to scuttle.
Constantinople Agreement: Britain, France and the Russian Empire agree to give Constantinople and the Bosphorus to Russia in case of victory (the treaty is later nullified by the Bolshevik Revolution).
June 24 – Mary Pickford becomes the first movie star to sign a million-dollar contract, making her one of the highest-paid people in the world.
August 30 – The crew of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition's Endurance is rescued from Elephant Island.
February 12 – WWI: Battle of Salaita Hill (East African Campaign) – South African and other British Empire troops fail to take a German East African defensive position.

July 1–November 18 – WWI: Battle of the Somme, opening with explosion of the British Y Sap and Lochnagar mines and the Battle of Albert: More than one million soldiers die, with 57,470 British Empire casualties on the first day, 19,240 of them killed, the British Army's bloodiest day. The immediate result is tactically inconclusive.
September 13 – Mary, a circus elephant, is hanged in the town of Erwin, Tennessee for killing her handler, Walter "Red" Eldridge.
August 10 – A general strike begins in Spain; it is smashed after 3 days with 70 left dead, hundreds of wounded and 2,000 arrests.
April 10 – Eddystone explosion: an explosion at an ammunition plant near Chester, Pennsylvania, kills 139, mostly female workers.

April 17
(N.S.) (April 4, O.S.) – Vladimir Lenin's April Theses are published. They become very influential in the following July Days and Bolshevik Revolution.
WWI: The Egyptian Expeditionary Force begins the Second Battle of Gaza. This unsuccessful frontal attack on strong Ottoman defences along with the first battle, results in 10,000 casualties, the dismissal of force commander General Archibald Murray, and the beginning of the Stalemate in Southern Palestine.
The Times and the Daily Mail (London newspapers both owned by Lord Northcliffe) print atrocity propaganda of the supposed existence of a German Corpse Factory processing dead soldiers' bodies.
September 14 (September 1 Old Style) – Russia is declared a republic by the Provisional Government.
(N.S.) (April 4, O.S.) – Vladimir Lenin's April Theses are published. They become very influential in the following July Days and Bolshevik Revolution.

Execution of the Romanov family: By order of the Bolshevik Party, and carried out by the Cheka, former emperor Nicholas II, his wife Alexandra Feodorovna, their children, Olga, Tatiana, Maria, Anastasia, Alexei and retainers are shot at the Ipatiev House, in Ekaterinburg, Russia.

December 1
By the Danish–Icelandic Act of Union, Iceland regains independence, but remains in personal union with the King of Denmark, who also becomes the King of Iceland.
New voting laws in Sweden makes votes no longer dependent on taxable assets, each adult having one vote.
The Union of Alba Iulia is proclaimed: Following the March 27 incorporation of Bessarabia and Bucovina, Transylvania unites with the Kingdom of Romania.
The Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes (which later becomes the Kingdom of Yugoslavia) is proclaimed, in particular ending Serbia's existence as a sovereign state for the next 87 years (it would not regain its sovereignty until ).
September 15–18 – WWI: Battle of Dobro Pole in the Vardar Offensive of the Balkans Campaign: The Allied Army of the Orient defeats Bulgarian defenders.
October 1 – WWI: The Desert Mounted Corps captures Damascus.
September 12–15 – WWI: Battle of Saint-Mihiel – Americans take a German salient.
August 27 – South African Prime Minister Louis Botha dies in office of 'Spanish flu'.
January 2–22 – Russian Civil War: The Red Army's Caspian-Caucasian Front begins the Northern Caucasus Operation against the White Army, but fails to make progress.
March 3–April – Russian Civil War: Beginning of the Chapan War as peasants of the provinces of Samara and Simbirsk rebel against Soviet rule.
Scuttling of the German fleet at Scapa Flow: Admiral Ludwig von Reuter scuttles the German fleet interned at Scapa Flow, Scotland; nine German sailors are killed.
March 23 – Benito Mussolini founds his Italian Fascist political movement in Milan.

February 24 – Adolf Hitler presents his National Socialist Program in Munich to the German Workers' Party (Deutsche Arbeiterpartei), which renames itself as the Nazi Party (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei).
Presidential elections begin in Mexico.

The so-called Spanish flu pandemic ends with an estimated total of between seventeen and fifty million dead since. It would be the last global pandemic until the swine flu pandemic almost 90 years later.
January 7 – Russian Civil War: The forces of Russian White Admiral Alexander Kolchak surrender in Krasnoyarsk; the Great Siberian Ice March ensues.
France occupies the Memel Territory of East Prussia.

June 10 – Paris declaration: Representatives of the three states of Transcaucasia and the North Caucasus (the Armenian, Azerbaijani and Georgian Socialist Soviet Republics) proclaim their independence, establishing a customs union and military alliance, not internationally recognized.

March 16
Treaty of Moscow establishes friendly relations between the Government of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey and the Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic.
Six Irish Republican Army men of the Forgotten Ten are hanged in Mountjoy Prison, Dublin.

October 5
The World Series baseball game in North America is first broadcast on the radio, by Newark, New Jersey, station WJZ, Pittsburgh station KDKA, and a group of other commercial and amateur stations throughout the eastern United States.
Constitution of Liechtenstein granted by Johann II, Prince of Liechtenstein, making the country a constitutional monarchy.
November 23 – In the United States, the Sheppard–Towner Act is signed by President Harding, providing federal funding for maternity and child care.
June 27 – The first signings of Treaty 11, an agreement between George V, King of Canada, and various Canadian First Nations, are conducted at Fort Providence.
September 18 – The Kingdom of Hungary joins the League of Nations.
Vegemite is invented by Australian entrepreneur Fred Walker.
June 26 – Louis Honoré Charles Antoine Grimaldi becomes Reigning Prince Louis II of Monaco.
November 14 – The British Broadcasting Company begins radio service in the United Kingdom, broadcasting from station 2LO in London.
June 24 – Weimar Republic foreign minister Walther Rathenau is assassinated; the murderers are captured on July 17.

The Kantō Massacre begins and continues for several weeks. Ethnic Koreans are killed by lynch mobs based on rumors that Koreans are committing crimes and plotting to overthrow the government. The death toll (and even the occurrence of) the massacre is disputed, with figures ranging from a few dozen to over 6,000 deaths. Most of the deaths were of Korean people, although it is said that other ethnic minorities and even Japanese people with unusual dialects were also killed.
October 1 – The Johor–Singapore Causeway opens to public traffic.
October 14 – The fourth tropical storm of the year forms just north of Panama.
November 11 – Adolf Hitler is arrested for his leading role in the Beer Hall Putsch.
April 12 – The Kandersteg International Scout Centre comes into existence in Switzerland.
Babbs Switch fire: A flash fire at a Christmas celebration in a one-room schoolhouse in Babbs, Oklahoma, United States, kills 36 people, mostly small children.
November 10 – The Trial of the 149 begins in Estonia, eventually resulting in the conviction of 129 communists, including several members of the Riigikogu.

October 10 – Voting in federal elections becomes compulsory in Australia, after a private member's bill proposed by Tasmanian Nationalist senator Herbert Payne results in the passing of the Commonwealth Electoral (Compulsory Voting) Act.

October 29 – In the United Kingdom, the Conservative Party, led by Stanley Baldwin, wins a landslide victory over the Labour Party, led by Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald, which had been governing in a minority since January.
January 22 – Ramsay MacDonald becomes the first Labour Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
November 24 – The silent film El Húsar de la Muerte is released in Santiago, Chile.
March 21 – Ravel's opera L'enfant et les sortilèges, to a libretto by Colette, is premiered at the Opéra de Monte-Carlo.
November 28 – The weekly country music-variety radio programme Grand Ole Opry is first broadcast on WSM radio in Nashville, Tennessee, as the "WSM Barn Dance".
April 20 – Iranian forces of Reza Shah occupy Ahvaz and arrest Sheikh Khazʽal Ibn Jabir.
October 1 – The US Congress grants permission for Gutzon Borglum to begin constructing Mount Rushmore National Memorial on federal land in South Dakota.

December 23 – Nicaraguan President Adolfo Díaz requests U.S. military assistance in the ongoing civil war. American peacekeeping troops immediately set up neutral zones in Puerto Cabezas and at the mouth of the Rio Grande to protect American and foreign lives and property.
Crown Prince Nguyễn Phúc Vĩnh Thuy ascends the throne as Bảo Đại, the last monarch of the Nguyễn dynasty of the Kingdom of Vietnam.
January 21 – The Belgian Parliament accepts the Locarno Treaties.
November 25 – The death penalty is re-established in Italy.
August 1 – In Mexico, the entry into force of anticlerical measures stipulated in the Constitution of causes the Cristero War from August 3.
December 30 – The first Asian commuter metro line, the Tokyo Metro Ginza Line, opens in Japan.
July 24 – The Menin Gate is dedicated as a war memorial at Ypres, Belgium.

April 12 Incident (Shanghai Massacre): Kuomintang troops kill a number of communist-supporting workers in Shanghai. The 1st United Front between the Nationalists and Communist ends, and the Civil War lasting until begins.
The Harlem Globetrotters exhibition basketball team play their first ever road game in Hinckley, Illinois.
October – Niels Bohr presents his theoretical principle of complementarity at the Fifth Solvay Conference on Physics.
April 19 – Publication of the original Oxford English Dictionary is completed after 70 years with issue of the last section ("wise – wyze") in Oxford.
Boston Garden opens in Boston, Massachusetts.
August 2 – Italy and Ethiopia sign the Italo-Ethiopian Treaty.
April 12 – A bomb attack against Italian Fascist leader Benito Mussolini in Milan kills 17 bystanders.
June 24 – A Swedish aeroplane rescues some survivors of the Italian North Pole expedition, including Umberto Nobile. The Soviet icebreaker Krasin saves the rest July 12.

March 4 – The National Revolutionary Party (Partido Nacional Revolucionario) is established in Mexico, by ex-President Plutarco Elías Calles. Under a succession of names, it will hold power in the country continuously for the next 71 years.

January 6
6 January Dictatorship: King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution.
Albanian missionary sister Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu, later known as Mother Teresa, arrives in Calcutta from Ireland to begin her work in India.
July 29 – the French prime minister Raymond Poincaré resigns, and is succeeded by Aristide Briand.

November 7 – In New York City, the Museum of Modern Art opens to the public. The first exhibition Cézanne, Gauguin, van Gogh and Seurat (November 7 – December 7) is seen by 47.000 visitors; the curator is Alfred H. Barr.
November – Vladimir Zworykin takes out the first patent for color television.
November 3 – Getúlio Vargas becomes president of Brazil.
Bernhard Schmidt invents the Schmidt camera.
May 24 – Amy Johnson lands in Darwin, Australia, becoming the first woman to fly solo from England to Australia (she left on May 5 for the 11,000 mile flight).

April 6
In an act of civil disobedience, Mahatma Gandhi breaks the salt laws of British India by making salt by the sea at the end of the Salt March.
The International Left Opposition is founded in Paris, France.
May 6 – The 7.1 Mw Salmas earthquake shakes northwestern Iran and southeastern Turkey, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX ; up to 3,000 people are killed.
December 9 – The Spanish Constituent Cortes approves the Spanish Constitution of, effectively establishing the Second Spanish Republic.
October 11 – A rally in Bad Harzburg, Germany leads to the Harzburg Front being founded, uniting the NSDAP, the DNVP, the Stahlhelm and various other right-wing factions.
July 16 – Emperor Haile Selassie signs the first Constitution of Ethiopia.
February 21 – Peruvian revolutionaries hijack a Ford Trimotor aeroplane, and demand that the pilot drop propaganda leaflets over Lima.
April 22 – Austria, the UK, Denmark, Germany, Italy, Sweden and the United States recognize the Spanish Republic.
Walter B. Pitkin publishes Life Begins at Forty in the United States.
U.S. president Herbert Hoover supports armament limitations at the World Disarmament Conference.

Walt Disney's Flowers and Trees, the first animated cartoon to be presented in full Technicolor, premieres in Los Angeles. It releases in theaters, along with the film version of Eugene O'Neill's Strange Interlude (starring Norma Shearer and Clark Gable); Flowers and Trees goes on to win the first Academy Award for Best Animated Short.
March 22 – Tarzan the Ape Man premieres in New Yord City, first of the classic film series starring Johnny Weissmuller and Maureen O'Sullivan.
January 28 – January 28 incident: Conflict between Japan and China in Shanghai.
April 4 – American airship Akron crashes off the coast of New Jersey, killing 73 of its 76 crewmen. It is the worst aviation accident in history up to this date (and until ).

October 12 – The United States Army Disciplinary Barracks on Alcatraz is acquired by the United States Department of Justice, which plans to incorporate the island into its Federal Bureau of Prisons as a penitentiary.
Mohammad Zahir Shah becomes King of Afghanistan at the age of 19, following the assassination of his father King Mohammad Nadir Shah.

April 5
The International Court of Justice in The Hague decides that Greenland belongs to Denmark, and condemns Norwegian landings on eastern Greenland. Norway submits to the decision.
United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt declares a national emergency and issues Executive Order 6102, making it illegal for U.S. citizens to own substantial amounts of monetary gold or bullion.

November 8
New Deal: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt unveils the Civil Works Administration, an organization designed to create jobs for more than 4 million of the unemployed.
Mohammad Zahir Shah becomes King of Afghanistan at the age of 19, following the assassination of his father King Mohammad Nadir Shah.
June 27 – Imam Yahya of Yemen and Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia conclude a peace treaty.
July 1 – The Hays Code begins to be strictly enforced in the Hollywood film industry, lasting until.

October 6 – Events of October the 6th: the President of Catalonia, Lluís Companys, declares the Catalan State of the Spanish Federal Republic, but Spanish troops swiftly crush the Catalan forces, and arrest him and the members of the Catalan government. The autonomy of Catalonia is suspended until.
July 25 – July Putsch: Austrian Nazis assassinate chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, during a failed coup attempt.
January 15 – The 8.0 Mw Nepal–Bihar earthquake strikes Nepal and Bihar with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI, killing an estimated 6,000–10,700 people.
June 9 – He–Umezu Agreement: China's Kuomintang government concedes Japanese military control of north-eastern China.

February 26
In Nazi Germany, Adolf Hitler orders reinstatement of the air force, the Luftwaffe, in violation of the Treaty of Versailles.
Robert Watson-Watt first demonstrates the use of radar to detect aircraft, at Daventry in the UK.
October 22 – The Chinese Communist Party settles in Shaanxi after the Long March.

December 12
The Lebensborn program in support of Nazi eugenics is founded by Heinrich Himmler in Germany.
The De La Warr Pavilion at Bexhill-on-Sea, designed by Erich Mendelsohn and Serge Chermayeff, a pioneering example of International Style architecture, opens in England.
January 24 – The first canned beer is sold in Richmond, Virginia, United States, by Gottfried Krueger Brewing Company.
November 12 – In California, the San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge opens to traffic.
Nestlé introduce the white chocolate Milkybar (called Galak in Continental Europe and elsewhere).

December 10 – Edward VIII abdication crisis: King Edward VIII of the United Kingdom signs an instrument of abdication at Fort Belvedere, Surrey in the presence of his three brothers, The Duke of York, The Duke of Gloucester and The Duke of Kent.
West China Famine: An estimated five million people die.
September 5 – Spanish Civil War: Robert Capa's photograph The Falling Soldier is taken.
The Vibora Luviminda sugar plantation trade unions strike on Maui island, Hawaii.
Memorial Day massacre of : The Chicago Police Department shoot and kill 10 unarmed demonstrators in Chicago.
February 21 – The League of Nations Non-Intervention Committee prohibits foreign nationals from fighting in the Spanish Civil War.
July 20 – The Geibeltbad Pirna water sports facility is opened in Dresden, Germany.
The Bombing of Jaén is carried out in Spain, by the Condor Legion of the Nazi German Luftwaffe.
As the Polish army masses along the Czech border, the Soviet Union warns Poland that if it crosses the Czech frontier, Russia will regard the non-aggression pact between the two countries as void.

July 22 – Britain rejects a proposal from its ambassador in Berlin, Nevile Henderson, for a four-power summit on Czechoslovakia consisting of Britain, France, Germany and the U.S.S.R., as London will under no circumstances accept the U.S.S.R. as a diplomatic partner.
January 27 – The Honeymoon Bridge at Niagara Falls, New York, collapses as a result of an ice jam.
Spanish Civil War: Alicante is bombed by fascist rebels, resulting in 313 deaths.
The New England hurricane in the United States strikes Long Island and southern New England, killing over 300 along the Rhode Island shoreline and 600 altogether.
British battleship HMS Nelson strikes a mine (laid by U-31) off the coast of Scotland, and is laid up for repairs until August.
May 14 – Lina Medina, a 5-year-old Peruvian girl, gives birth to a baby boy, becoming the youngest confirmed mother in medical history.

WWII: Battle of Westerplatte ends when Polish troops on the Westerplatte are forced by lack of food and ammunition to surrender. The garrison of about two hundred had held out against thousands of German forces (many of them naval officer cadets from the Schleswig-Holstein) for seven days.
April 1 – The Spanish Civil War comes to an end when the last of the Republican forces surrender.
October 6 – WWII: The Battle of Kock ends the Polish Campaign. Polish resistance moves underground.
April 16 – In American baseball, the Cleveland Indians, behind Bob Feller's Opening Day no-hitter, defeat the Chicago White Sox, 1–0.
Recruitment begins in Britain for a volunteer home defence force: the Local Defence Volunteers, later known as the Home Guard.

March 18 – WWII: Axis powers – Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini meet at Brenner Pass in the Alps. After being informed by Hitler that the Germans are ready to attack in the west, Mussolini agrees to bring Italy into the war in due course.

November 5 United States presidential election: Democrat incumbent Franklin D. Roosevelt decisively defeats Republican challenger Wendell Willkie, and becomes the United States' first and only third-term president.
WWII: Allied Convoy HX 84 is attacked by German cruiser Admiral Scheer in the North Atlantic; the sacrifice of escorting British armed merchant cruiser HMS Jervis Bay under Capt. Edward Fegen and SS Beaverford enables a majority of the ships (including tanker MV San Demetrio) to escape.
Occupation of the Baltic states: The Soviet Union occupies Estonia and Latvia.
WWII: British aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal sinks under tow off Gibraltar, after being torpedoed the previous day by German submarine U-81.
German troopship Bahia Laura is sunk by British submarine HMS Trident ; 450 are killed.
September 29–30 – The Holocaust: Babi Yar massacre – German troops, assisted by Ukrainian police and local collaborators, kill 33,771 Jews in Kyiv.
WWII: The Japanese invade the Shanghai International Settlement, to occupy the British and the American sectors, after the attack on Pearl Harbor.

June 4 – Guidelines for the Conduct of the Troops in Russia are issued by Nazi high-command through OKW. This order (a lesser known precursor to the Commisar Order) explicitly commands that Jews (in addition to Bolshevik partisans and Commisars) be killed. In a sense, this order – in combination with the Commissar Order about to be delivered, and Goring's instruction to Heydrich to look into logistics later in the month, that is mentioned at the beginning of the Wannsee Conference of the following year – inaugurates the European Holocaust of the Jews.
March 16 – WWII: New Zealand and Australia declare war on Thailand.

February 19 – WWII:
Bombing of Darwin: The Japanese 1st Air Fleet under Admiral Chūichi Nagumo bombs Darwin, Australia. This force comprises the aircraft carriers Akagi, Kaga, Hiryū and Sōryū and a powerful force of escorting surface ships. During the attack, 188 planes led by Mitsuo Fuchida destroy 11 vessels and wreck a lot of the harbor infrastructure, killing some 240 people.
A returning Japanese fighter plane crashes on Melville Island and its pilot, Hajime Toyoshima, becomes the first Japanese captured on Australian soil, when indigenous resident Matthias Ulungura takes him prisoner.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs Executive Order 9066, allowing the United States military to define areas as exclusionary zones. These zones affect the Japanese on the West Coast, and Germans and Italians primarily on the East Coast.

September 10
WWII: North Atlantic convoy ON 127 is attacked by U-boats, sinking 6 ships.
The Women's Auxiliary Ferrying Squadron begins operation in the United States.
Burma campaign: Japanese forces of the 15 Army under General Shōjirō Iida capture Lashio. The allies are in full retreat.
Battle of Bataan: The Bataan Peninsula falls, American and Filipino forces (some 75,000 soldiers) surrender to the Japanese 14th Army under General Masaharu Homma.
The Memphis Belle's crew becomes the first aircrew in the 8th Air Force to complete its 25-mission tour of duty. The aircraft and crew are the first to return to the U.S. intact for a War Bond drive.

October 14
WWII: During the Second Raid on Schweinfurt, the United States Eighth Air Force suffers so many losses, that it loses air supremacy over Germany for several months.
The Holocaust: Uprising in Sobibór extermination camp; about half the inmates escape. Three days later, the camp is closed.
José P. Laurel takes the oath of office as President of the Philippines (Second Philippine Republic).

WWII: Signing of Moscow Declarations: the Declaration of the Four Nations on general security, by the United States, United Kingdom, Soviet Union and Republic of China; and the Declarations on Italy, Austria and Atrocities by the first three governments.
Edward R. Murrow delivers his classic "Orchestrated Hell" broadcast over CBS Radio, describing a Royal Air Force nighttime bombing raid on Berlin.
August 6 – WWII: Battle of Vella Gulf: Americans defeat a Japanese convoy off Kolombangara, as the U.S. Army drives the Japanese out of Munda airfield on New Georgia.
WWII: The Romanian capital Bucharest is captured by the Red Army.
The Dumbarton Oaks Conference concludes.
WWII: Operation Margarethe: German forces occupy Hungary.

May 14 – The Holocaust: Predominantly Muslim Albanian troops of the 21st Waffen Mountain Division of the SS Skanderbeg (1st Albanian) round up 281 Jews in Priština, and hand them over to the Germans for transportation to Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.
June 15 – WWII: Battle of Saipan: United States forces land on Saipan.
General Alexander Löhr, Commander of German Army Group E near Topolšica, Slovenia, signs the capitulation of German occupation troops.
Admiral Karl Dönitz orders all U-boats to cease offensive operations and return to bases in Norway.
A Communist-led government is formed in Romania under Petru Groza, following Soviet intervention.
Prague uprising: Prague rises up against occupying Nazi forces, encouraged by radio broadcasts (giving rise to the Battle for Czech Radio).
The Red Army pushes most of the Axis forces out of Hungary into Austria.
January 28 – The Canadian schooner Bluenose founders on a Haitian reef.
July 21 – An Irgun bomb explodes in Jerusalem, due to secretive talks between Jews and Britain to consolidate the state of Israel.
April 3 – Japanese Lt. General Masaharu Homma is executed outside Manila in the Philippines, for leading the Bataan Death March.
October 24–November 11 – Bihar riots: Hindu mobs target Muslim families in the Indian state of Bihar, resulting in anywhere between 2,000 and 30,000 deaths.

January 31
The last session of the Permanent Court of International Justice occurs.
Yugoslavia's new constitution, modeling the Soviet Union, establishes 6 constituent republics (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia and Slovenia).
The U.S. Army Ordnance Corps Hermes program V-2 rocket Blossom I is launched into space, carrying plant material and fruitflies, the first living things to enter space.
May 1 – Portella della Ginestra massacre: The Salvatore Giuliano gang of Sicilian separatists opens fire on a Labour Day parade at Portella della Ginestra, Sicily, killing 11 people and wounding 27.

August 15
The greater Indian subcontinent, with a mixed population of Hindu, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Zoroasters, Jews, Christians, Muslims and others formed by the Partition of India, gains independence from the British Empire, as the Dominion of India. 190 years British rule (1757–) in India comes to an end.
Jawaharlal Nehru takes office as the first prime minister of India, taking his oath from Louis Mountbatten, Viscount Mountbatten of Burma, Governor-General of India (but no longer viceroy).

February 20
An explosion at the O'Connor Electro-Plating Company in Los Angeles leaves 17 dead, 100 buildings damaged, and a 22-foot-deep (6.7 m) crater in the ground.
The U.S. Army Ordnance Corps Hermes program V-2 rocket Blossom I is launched into space, carrying plant material and fruitflies, the first living things to enter space.
March 25 – A coal mine explosion in Centralia, Illinois, United States; 111 miners are killed.

November 27 – The Calgary Stampeders defeat the Ottawa Rough Riders 12–7 before 20,013 fans at Toronto's Varsity Stadium, to win their first Grey Cup and complete the only perfect season to date in Canadian football.

April 9
Liberal politician Jorge Eliécer Gaitán's assassination provokes a violent riot in Bogotá (the Bogotazo) and a further 10 years of violence (La Violencia) across Colombia.
The Deir Yassin massacre takes place in British Mandatory Palestine.

January 5 – In the United States:
Warner Brothers shows the first color newsreel (Tournament of Roses Parade and the Rose Bowl Game).
The first Kinsey Report, Sexual Behavior in the Human Male, is published.
March 8 – McCollum v. Board of Education: The United States Supreme Court rules that religious instruction in public schools violates the U.S. Constitution.
August 27 – Whittaker Chambers states that Alger Hiss was a communist on Meet the Press radio.

May 20
The AFSA (predecessor of the NSA) is established.
The Kuomintang regime declares martial law in Taiwan, which lasts until.
July 24 (St John's Day) – Eruption of the Cumbre Vieja volcano on La Palma begins.
November 7 – Oil is discovered beneath the Caspian Sea, off the coast of the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic.
Warner Bros. cartoon, "Fast and Furry-ous" is released. It also marks the debut of Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner. The director is Chuck Jones (credited as Charles M. Jones).
June 5 – Thailand elects Orapin Chaiyakan, the first Thai female member of Thailand's Parliament.
October 30 – The Jayuya Uprising is started by Puerto Rican Nationalists against the United States-supported government.
August 6 – Monarchist demonstrations lead to a riot in Brussels.
August 15 – The 8.6 Mw Assam–Tibet earthquake shakes the region, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI, killing about 4,800 people.
United States President Harry S. Truman orders the development of the hydrogen bomb, in response to the detonation of the Soviet Union's first atomic bomb in.
Laos gets involved in the First Indochina War, to overthrow the French Army.
West Germany joins UNESCO.
May 1 – The opera house of Geneva, Switzerland is almost destroyed in a fire.
October 3–8 – Korean War: First Battle of Maryang-san – United Nations (primarily Australian) forces drive back the Chinese.
October 6 – Malayan Emergency: Communist insurgents kill British commander Sir Henry Gurney.

February 12
The seven-nation Commonwealth Consultative Committee meets to discuss the Colombo Plan for south and south-east Asia.
Muhammad Reza Shah marries Soraya Esfandiary-Bakhtiari.
June 10 – San Juan earthquake. A magnitude 6.8 earthquake kills five people on Argentina's San Juan Province.
July 19–August 3 – The Summer Olympics are held in Helsinki, Finland.
The Roman Catholic Church bans the books of André Gide.
United States presidential election: Republican General Dwight D. Eisenhower defeats Democratic Governor of Illinois Adlai Stevenson (correctly predicted by the UNIVAC computer).
October 17 – 17 October affair: Indonesian troops led by General Nasution surround the presidential palace, seeking the dismissal of the People's Representative Council; Sukarno avoids confrontation.
President Eisenhower delivers his "Chance for Peace" speech, to the National Association of Newspaper Editors.
September 4 – The discovery of REM sleep is first published, by researchers Eugene Aserinsky and Nathaniel Kleitman.
August 20 – The French government ousts King Mohammed V of Morocco, and exiles him to Corsica.

February 11
United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower refuses a clemency appeal for Ethel and Julius Rosenberg.
The Soviet Union breaks diplomatic relations with Israel, after a bomb explodes at the Soviet Embassy, in reaction to the 'Doctors' plot'.

August 12
The Ionian earthquake of magnitude 7.2 totally devastates Cephalonia and most of the other Ionian Islands, in Greece's worst natural disaster in centuries.
Soviet atomic bomb project: "Joe 4", the first Soviet thermonuclear weapon, is detonated at Semipalatinsk Test Site, Kazakh SSR.
January 7 – Georgetown–IBM experiment: The first public demonstration of a machine translation system is held in New York, at the head office of IBM.
The 26th Academy Awards Ceremony is held.

July 31 – Italian expedition to K2: Italian mountaineers Lino Lacedelli and Achille Compagnoni become the first to reach the summit of the second highest mountain in the world, in the Karakoram range.

October 11
Pre-Vietnam War: The Viet Minh takes control of North Vietnam.
Hurricane Hazel crosses over Haiti, killing 1,000.
February 25 – Lt. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes premier of Egypt.

December 1 – In Montgomery, Alabama, Rosa Parks refuses to obey bus driver James F. Blake's order that she give up her seat to make room for a white passenger, and is arrested, leading to the Montgomery bus boycott.
September 6 – Istanbul pogrom: Istanbul's Greek minority is the target of a government-sponsored pogrom.
The Tappan Zee Bridge over the Hudson River, in New York State, opens to traffic.
The military coup to unseat President Juan Perón of Argentina is launched at midnight.
September 14 – Pope Pius XII elevates many of the apostolic vicariates in Africa to Metropolitan Archdioceses.
February 14–25 – The 20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union is held in Moscow.
June 14 – The Flag of the United States Army is formally dedicated.
June 21 – Playwright Arthur Miller appears before the House Un-American Activities Committee in Washington, D.C.
May 8 – The constitutional union between Indonesia and the Netherlands is dissolved.
The Game of the Century : 13-year-old Bobby Fischer beats grandmaster Donald Byrne, in the Rosenwald Memorial Tournament in New York City.
May 8 – South Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem begins a state visit to the United States, his regime's main sponsor.
September 9 – The Civil Rights Act of is enacted, establishing the United States Commission on Civil Rights.
September 5 – Cuban Revolution: Fulgencio Batista’s forces bomb anti-government riots in Cienfuegos.
Aquila Airways Solent crash: A flying boat crash on the Isle of Wight leaves 45 dead.
New Zealand general election: The Labour Party defeats the governing National Party, with Walter Nash succeeding Keith Holyoake as Prime Minister.
The Law of Permanent Defense of Democracy, which outlawed the Communist Party of Chile and banned 26,650 persons from the electoral lists, is repealed.

December 16
A fire breaks out in the Vida Department Store in Bogotá, Colombia and kills 84 persons.
Soviet polar pilot V. M. Perov on Li-2 rescues four Belgian polar explorers, led by Gaston de Gerlache, who have survived a plane crash in Antarctica 250 km from their base five days earlier.
August 30–September 1 – Notting Hill race riots: Riots occur between blacks and whites in Notting Hill, London.
November 10 – Harry Winston donates the Hope Diamond to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.
October 11 – Pioneer 1, the second and most successful of the 3 project Able space probes, becomes the first spacecraft launched by the newly formed NASA.

January 2 – Soviet lunar probe Luna 1 is the first human-made object to attain escape velocity from Earth. It reaches the vicinity of Earth's Moon, where it was intended to crash-land, but instead becomes the first spacecraft to go into heliocentric orbit.
October 13 – The United States launches research satellite Explorer 7.
American Airlines begins the first U.S. domestic jet service with a Boeing 707 airliner flight between New York and Los Angeles.
November 20 – The Declaration of the Rights of the Child is adopted by the United Nations.
Léopoldville riots: At least 49 people are killed during clashes between the police and participants of a meeting of the ABAKO Party in Léopoldville in the Belgian Congo.
Antoine Gizenga proclaims in the Democratic Republic of the Congo that he has taken over as the country's premier.
March 23 – Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev meets French President Charles de Gaulle in Paris.
August 25 – The Summer Olympic Games begin in Rome.

September 26 – United States presidential debates: The two leading candidates in the United States presidential election, John F. Kennedy and Richard Nixon, participate in the first live televised presidential debate.
Sultan Hisamuddin Alam Shah, Sultan of Selangor and 2nd Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia, dies in office. He is replaced by Tuanku Syed Putra, Raja of Perlis.
The old Deutsche Opernhaus in the Berlin neighborhood of Charlottenburg is returned to its newly rebuilt house, as the Deutsche Oper Berlin.

September 1
The Eritrean War of Independence begins with the Battle of Adal in which Hamid Idris Awate and his companions shoot at Ethiopian police and military. The war will continue until.
The first meeting of the Non-Aligned Movement is held. The Soviet Union resumes nuclear testing, escalating fears over the ongoing Berlin Crisis.
Vostok 1: Soviet cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin becomes the first human in space, orbiting the Earth once before parachuting to the ground.
The New Democratic Party of Canada is founded, with the merger of the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation and the Canadian Labour Congress.
February 4 – The Portuguese Colonial War begins in Angola.
September 25 – Sonny Liston knocks out Floyd Patterson two minutes into the first round of his fight for the boxing world title in Chicago.
April 13 – OAS leader Edmond Jouhaud is sentenced to death in France.
November 29 – An agreement is signed between Britain and France, to develop the Concorde supersonic airliner.
The first attack helicopter company, Utility Tactical Transport Helicopter Company, of the United States Army is formed on Okinawa Island, Japan.
In West Germany, a coalition government of Christian Democrats, Christian Socialists and Free Democrats is formed.
